title-group.article-title: Thermophysical and mechanical properties of TiO2 and silica nanoparticle-filled natural rubber composites

article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemical Sciences, Mahatma Gandhi University, Kottayam, Kerala, India
2Université Paris-Est, Créteil Val de Marne CERTES, Créteil Cedex, France

author-notes.corresp: A Boudenne, Université Paris-Est, Créteil Val de Marne CERTES, 61 Av. du Général de Gaulle, 94010 Créteil Cedex, France Email: boudenne@u-pec.fr

abstract.p: The mechanical and thermophysical properties of natural rubber filled with titanium dioxide (TiO2) and nanosilica composites have been investigated at room temperature for several filler concentrations. It is observed that the thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity of the composites increase with filler loading, independent of the nature of the filler. We show that the thermal heat transport through composites is affected by the geometry of the fillers as well as the particle size and specific surface area of the fillers. The measured values of thermal conductivity have been compared to some theoretical models. The mechanical properties of the composites have also been studied and results have been correlated with thermal conductivity data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
For the past few decades, polymer nanocomposites have attracted considerable attention because of the improvement in mechanical, thermal, barrier and flame retardant properties. 1
–5 The advantage is that reinforcement could be achieved at very low loading, less than 10 wt.% of fillers, whereas 30–70 wt.% is often required in conventional polymer composites. 6 In the tyre industry, fillers are used to increase the abrasion resistance, strength and modulus of rubber. Carbon black has been the traditional reinforcing filler for rubber because it provides excellent reinforcement to general purpose rubbers at a relatively low cost. Nowadays, a variety of nonblack fillers are widely used in the rubber industry to improve and modify the physical properties of elastomeric materials. 7
–11 Calcium carbonate, clay, precipitated silica, talc and titanium dioxide (TiO2) are used in white sidewall compounds to impart desired physical properties and appearance. 12

Silica is one of the most common fillers used in the reinforcement of elastomers especially for nonblack applications, as for example, for light-colored products. The presence of silanol groups on the silica surface induces particle–particle interaction which tends to favor filler agglomeration in the rubber matrix. 13 This highly polar surface makes it poor compatible with most rubbers due to weak rubber–filler interactions. However, silica has been widely used in rubber industry, particularly in tyre applications because it provides several advantages over carbon black as for instance, the improvement in rolling resistance, wear resistance and wet traction when it is used in combination with silane coupling agent. 14,15 Silica/carbon black dual fillers have recently been used as reinforcement in natural rubber (NR). 16

A lot of articles related to the experimental and theoretical investigation of the thermophysical behavior of polymer filled with nanoparticles have been reported in the literature. 17
–21 A randomly mixed model was introduced by Zhang et al. 17 to estimate the thermal conductivity of particle-filled composites. Recently, a laser flash technique has been used to evaluate the thermal conductivities of multiwall carbon nanotube (CNT)/silica nanocomposites. 18 The thermophysical properties of maleated polyethylene/layered silicate nanocomposites were investigated by Lee et al.; they reported a decrease in the thermal conductivity with increase in silicate content. 19 In polyurethane (PU)/layered silicate nanocomposites, the thermal conductivity showed a slight decrease with increase in silica content. 20 The effect of surface treatment of CNTs on the thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity of CNT reinforced polypropylene nanocomposites was investigated by Kim et al. using 3ω method. 21 They observed an increase in thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity with increase in CNT concentration.

To our knowledge, only few studies were devoted to thermal properties of rubber compounds. 22
–26 In this work, the thermophysical and the mechanical measurements of composites of NR filled with TiO2 and silica nanoparticles were carried out at room temperature. The effect of particle size and filler content on the thermal conductivity, diffusivity, tensile strength and dynamic modulus of the composites was investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: NR (ISNR-5) used as the polymer matrix in this study was supplied by Rubber Research Institute of India (RRII), Kottayam. The molecular weight of NR obtained by light scattering is Mn = 2.68 × 105 g/mol and Mw = 8.38 × 105 g/mol. All other ingredients used were of commercial grade and were kindly supplied by LANXESS (Germany).

TiO2 (KEMOX RC 800 PG) used as filler (particle diameter ≅190 nm) was supplied by Kerala Minerals and Metals Limited (KMML, Kollam, India). The surface modified nanosilica (particle diameter ≅13 nm) was obtained from Degussa, Germany.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: Compounding was performed in an open laboratory size two-roll mixing mill. NR was first masticated into the two-roll mill for about 2–3 min followed by the addition of the ingredients. Cure characteristics were analyzed using an oscillating disc rheometer (Monsanto R-100) at a temperature of 150°C. The composites were cured in a hydraulic press under a pressure of about 120 bar at 150°C. Samples with a parallelepiped shape having dimensions 44 mm length and 2.5 mm thickness were used for the thermophysical study. Tensile tests were performed on dumbbell-shaped specimens having thickness of 1.5 mm.

sec.title: Morphological analysis and density measurements
sec.p: The morphology of the cryo fractured composites was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM; JEOL 6400 WINSEM model at 5 keV). The surface topographic image analysis was performed by atomic force microscopy (Park systems XE-100 AFM, Korea).

The pycnometer method was used for measuring the density of the composites. The measurements were carried out with a balance and a pycnometer for the same square plate samples which were used for thermophysical study.

sec.title: Thermophysical and mechanical measurements
sec.p: A periodical method developed by Boudenne et al. 27 was used to estimate the thermal conductivity and diffusivity of polymer composite materials at room temperature. This method is based on the use of a small temperature modulation in a sample with 44 mm length and 2.5 mm thickness.

Tensile tests were performed according to the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D-412 using an Instron 4411 Universal Testing Machine at a crosshead speed of 500 mm/min. Five samples were tested and the average of the measured values was taken.

sec.title: Specific volume of composites
sec.p: The values of the density for the NR-TiO2 and NR–nanosilica composites are reported in Table 1. The difference observed does not seem to be significant. For a given weight fraction, the densities of NR-TiO2 and NR–nanosilica composites are very close.

caption.p: Results of thermal conductivity, thermal diffusivity, density, dynamic modulus and tensile strength of the composites a

fn.p: aSample coding: ‘T’ is given for TiO2 -filled NR and ‘NS’ for silica-filled NR The suffix indicates the filler loading expressed in weight percentage.

sec.p:
If the composite samples are well processed, that is a good homogeneity is achieved and there are no air bubbles in the sample, the density ρ of the composites should behave linearly upon the filler volume fraction φ, according to the following equation: 1
ρ
=
ρ

( 1 −

) +
ρ

Where ρm and ρf are the densities of the polymeric matrix and the filler, respectively.

The dependence of the density of composites on the filler volume fraction is shown in Figure 1. The experimental data are compared to the theoretical mixing rule (equation (1)). The observed linear variations indicate good mixing of the samples.

caption.p: Density versus filler volume fraction for TiO2 - and nanosilica-filled natural rubber (NR) composites. The symbols represent the experimental values and lines represent the theoretical mixing rule values.

sec.title: Thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity
sec.p: The incorporation of fillers can induce modifications on the thermal properties of the polymers. In fact, the dispersion and orientation of the filler particles, the filler aspect ratio, the relative ratio of thermal conductivity of the filler and the matrix affect the thermal properties of the composites.

sec.title: Effect of filler loading
sec.p: The experimental plot of the thermal conductivity upon filler volume fraction for both NR/TiO2 and NR/nanosilica composites is shown in Figure 2. The thermal conductivity was found to be increased when the filler volume fraction increase. The NR/TiO2 composites showed an increase of 41% of the thermal conductivity with only 9.84 vol.% of TiO2 (noted T40). For NR/nanosilica, an increase of 37% of the thermal conductivity for 6.48 vol.% of nanosilica (noted Ns20) was noticed.

caption.p: Thermal conductivity versus filler volume fraction for TiO2- and nanosilica-filled natural rubber (NR) composites.

sec.p:
Indeed, the increase in thermal conductivity of the composites with filler volume fraction is almost foreseeable, because the fillers have a higher thermal conductivity (
λ
T i O
2
= 11.7
W
m
− 1
K
− 1
and λsilica = 1.4 W m−1 K−1) 28 than the neat polymeric matrix (λm = 0.097 ± 0.001 W m−1 K−1).
It is observed that the thermal conductivity is almost the same for 7.57 vol.% (T30) and 9.84 vol.% (T40) of TiO2. This means the thermal conductivity of NR/TiO2 composite levels off beyond T30.

The thermophysical behavior of NR/silica system, that is the increase in thermal conductivity of the composites with silica content is opposite to the one observed by Yao et al. 20 for PU/layered silicate nanocomposites. This means that the addition of silica particles allows better heat transport in NR matrix. Besides, Keblinski et al. 29 proposed the possible mechanisms for enhancing the thermal conductivity and suggested that the size effect, the clustering of nanoparticles and the surface adsorption could be major reasons for this enhancement of thermal properties. According to their observation, the Brownian motion of nanoparticles contributes much less than the other factors.

The experimental plots of the thermal diffusivity obtained for all samples upon the corresponding filler volume fraction are shown in Figure 3. As observed in the case of thermal conductivity, the thermal diffusivity was also found to be increasing with increase in the filler content. The NR/TiO2 composites showed an increase of 28% in thermal diffusivity with only 9.84% volume fraction of TiO2 (i.e. T40). For NR/nanosilica, an increase of 26% of the thermal diffusivity for a silica volume fraction of 6.48 vol.% (i.e. Ns20) was observed. However, the statistical uncertainties are more important than for the thermal conductivity measurements.

caption.p: Thermal diffusivity versus filler volume fraction for TiO2- and nanosilica-filled natural rubber (NR) composites.

sec.title: Effect of particle size
sec.p: The values of thermal conductivity of the composites change with the nature of the filler, that is particle size, shape, morphology, filler aspect ratio and so on, can play a major role for the thermal transport of the composites. This is supported by the observation of only slightly higher values of thermal conductivity, ‘λ’ for NR composites with TiO2 (with particle diameter 190 nm) than those with silica particles (with particle diameter 12–13 nm) for comparable filler fractions, even if the thermal conductivity of TiO2 is about 8 times greater than the nanosilica.

The influence of the size of the fillers dispersed in the polymeric matrix is nonnegligible. Now, it is well known that in polymeric matrices filled with metallic or mineral particles, higher values of thermal conductivity are obtained using small particles for a given volume fraction, that is for increased particle/particle and particle/matrix contact surface areas. However, it is not easy to make this rule a general one because in parallel to this effect, an opposite effect related to the ability of the aggregation of the fillers can reduce the probability to form filler conductive chains. The 3D AFM images of NR composites with 7.57 vol.% and 9.84 vol.% of TiO2 presented in Figures 4(a) and 5(b), respectively, show the aggregation of TiO2 particles in the NR matrix. Figure 4(c) shows the agglomerates of nanoparticles of silica. A similar study was also performed using SEM in order to check the AFM results.

caption.p: Atomic force microscopy (AFM) 3D images of (a) T30 , (b) T40 and (c) Ns10 composites.

sec.title: Theoretical thermal conductivity models
sec.p: Many theoretical and empirical models have been proposed to predict the effective thermal conductivity of two-phase mixtures, but none of them has general validity. 30 –32 Most of the models previously reported in literature were established for polymers filled with spherical particles.

For a two-component composite, the simplest models consider materials arranged in either parallel or series with respect to the heat flow, which gives the upper or lower bounds of effective thermal conductivity. For the parallel conduction model: 2
λ

This model predicts fairly well the effective thermal conductivities at low filler concentrations; whereas for high filler concentrations, particles begin to touch each other and form conductive chains in the direction of heat flow, so this model underestimates the value of effective thermal conductivities in this region.

The Hatta and Taya model was referred to the second-order bounds model. 35 It takes into account the filler geometry as well as the perturbation between the matrix and the filler. This thermal conductivity model was developed with the analogy of the short fiber modulus at different orientation. The solution of the Hatta and Taya model for spherical inclusions is given by: 6

Figure 5 presents a comparison between the experimental values of thermal conductivity of the composites and some theoretical models. All data are plotted as a function of filler volume fraction. Computations were performed using the experimental thermal conductivity value of the NR matrix and those of the fillers. 28 As it is seen in Figure 6, the geometric mean model gives the best estimation of the thermal conductivity for both composites. However, for a high filler volume fraction of TiO2 , we note that the geometric mean model is not in agreement with experimental values of thermal conductivity of TiO2 -filled NR composites. This can be explained by the lower value of thermal conductivity of nanosilica (λsilica /λm = 14) compared to TiO2 (
λ
T i O
2
/
λ
m
=
12
0
). Indeed, it is well known that theoretical models fail in predicting accurate values of composite thermal conductivity of high values of the ratio between filler and matrix thermal conductivity values. This effect might influence not only the heat transport of composites but also the mechanical behavior. 36

caption.p: Comparison between experimental values of thermal conductivity of composites and some theoretical models.
Normalized dynamic modulus of TiO2- and nanosilica-filled natural rubber (NR) composites as a function of normalized thermal conductivity values at room temperature.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p:
The mechanical property measurements were carried out and the results were compared to the thermal conductivity behavior. This kind of comparative studies of some physical properties and the investigation of correlations between different properties was already done by several authors. 34
,
38 In our case, the composites showed a regular increase in modulus with increase in the filler content. In order to investigate the existence of correlation between the thermal conductivity and the mechanical properties, normalized dynamic modulus was plotted as a function of normalized thermal conductivity for the NR composites at room temperature. This is shown in Figure 6. The tensile strength also increased based on the amount of filler in the NR matrix. A plot of normalized tensile strength of TiO2 and nanosilica-filled NR composites as a function of normalized thermal conductivity values at room temperature is shown in Figure 7. In the NR/silica system, both the dynamic modulus and the tensile strength do not change significantly above 3.35 vol.% of silica (Ns10) as can be seen from Figures 6 and 7, whereas thermal conductivity still increases above this volume fraction. This is due to the silica network formation at this concentration which is also supported by the AFM image (Figure 4(c)). Thus, the correlation between thermal conductivity and mechanical properties exists only below this critical concentration. So, we can suppose that the aggregation of the fillers affects more the mechanical than the thermophysical properties. Indeed, the strong mechanical reinforcing effect of nanoparticles is partly lost when fillers start to agglomerate. On the contrary, thermal conductivity is more sensitive to the amount of filler used than to its homogeneous dispersion within the matrix. Thus, agglomeration of fillers has a greater influence on mechanical behavior than on the thermophysical one. The effect of this agglomeration appears for a greater filler volume fraction in the case of TiO2 . This might be either due to the fact that TiO2 particles have a greater size than nanosilica particles or because of a stronger ability of nanosilica particles to agglomerate compared to TiO2.

caption.p: Normalized tensile strength of TiO2- and nanosilica-filled natural rubber (NR) composites as a function of normalized thermal conductivity values at room temperature.

sec.p: It can be seen that there is a linear correlation between the dynamic modulus and the thermal conductivity up to a specific filler concentration and beyond that concentration, this correlation does not exist longer. As can be seen in Figure 6, it is obvious that the correlation does not exist beyond T30 and Ns10 ; for higher concentrations, the dispersion of particles within the matrix is not uniform.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In the present work, the thermophysical properties of NR/TiO2 and NR/silica nanocomposites have been investigated. Both thermal conductivity and the diffusivity values of filled NR composites are found to be higher than that of unfilled rubber. The thermophysical properties are found to be influenced by the geometry of the fillers as well as the particle size of the fillers.

The mechanical properties of the composites have also been studied to investigate the correlation between the thermal conductivity and mechanical properties of the material. The composites filled with silica exhibit higher tensile strength and dynamic modulus than the TiO2 -filled composites due to the strong interfacial interactions of nanosilica with the NR matrix. In this study, we have shown that the aggregations of the fillers affect more the mechanical than the thermophysical properties and that a clear correlation exists between the relative dynamic modulus, the relative conductivity and the relative tensile strength of the composites below the critical volume fraction where the particles start forming agglomerated structure (Ns10 and T30).

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received financial support from KSCSTE, Kerala, India and DST, India.
